So far the implementation only does:
* Remove the scheme (http://  https://)
* Removes common unspecific sub domains (m. www. mobile.) - Code borrowed from Fennec

I noticed two things:
* We only allow opening new tabs from the context menu. Using this I often opened a bunch of tabs  that are from the same "page". Meaning at least the domain (and sometimes parts of the path) are the same for a bunch of tabs. Making it hard or impossible to distinguish between them.
* Strictly following the spec I end up with pages that are reduced to the same "label":
** https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firefox_Focus -> m.wikipedia.org/wiki
** https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mozilla -> m.wikipedia.org/wiki

Picking a "label" from a URL is pretty hard. We had this discussion a bunch of times for Activity Stream and whatever algorithm we pick there are always cases where it doesn't work correctly. I understand that we need to somehow cut off the string if it's too long - but I'm not sure why we purposefully make it shorter if there's space to show more.

Unfortunately I have no other proposal. Sometimes the domain is important, sometimes the path and other times the page title is the most helpful.

Can't think of any way to prevent AppCompatDialogFragment from providing same package in getArguments(), so ignoring may be the best action. Tangentially: what behaviour should occur when there are no applications other than Focus available?

One note is that my solution compares to see if the packageName of each AppInfo is equal to the current application's packageName: if you are using, for example, Gecko, you will still be prompted to open the app in Focus. Could potentially instead filter based on the existence of the expression "org.mozilla.focus" within the AppInfo's packageName, but this is a little bit dirtier.

I think the larger issue is why are there four modes:

1. 2D
2. Fullscreen
3. Fullscreen + Focus Mode
4. Immersive Mode

Can we remove 2 and 3? And let content handle entering fullscreen, but allow the back-button to call `document.exitFullscreen` (à la the Escape key in desktop browsers).

If you check Vimeo, YouTube, etc., they already have their own Fullscreen icons. It is confusing to have in our browser UI an "Enter Fullscreen" when no other browser (VR, desktop, mobile) has one. It breaks product conventions and causes confusion to users.

What would make a lot of sense to have `<video>` elements to automatically enter a Fullscreen/Focus mode. Think iOS' auto-fullscreen video player.

And then add adjustable points at every corner of the window to resize the window.

That way, there is no confusion between toggling modes to achieve the appearance you want.
